column1: Apache Junction is a city in Maricopa and Pinal counties in the state of Arizona.  According to the 2019 U.S. Census estimates
column2: the population of the city was 42
column4: most of whom lived in Pinal County.

column1: Apache Junction is named for the junction of the Apache Trail and Old West Highway. The area where Apache Junction is located used to be known as Youngberg
column3: the westernmost peak of the Superstition Mountains

column1: == History ==
Apache Junction is located at an intersection on an unpaved stagecoach trail to the nearby Superstition Mountains.
Apache Junction became a historical landmark and scenic byway that was opened to the public in 1922 and is currently part of a 120
mile-long "circle trail" that begins and ends in Apache Junction.
== Geography ==
Apache Junction is at 33°24′54″N 111°32′46″W.Apache Junction is located in the eastern far east part of the Greater Phoenix Metropolitan area.
According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city has an area of 34.2 square miles (89 km2)

column1: The town is bounded by the Superstition Mountains (a federal wilderness area and home of the Lost Dutchman's Gold Mine) on the east
column2: the Goldfield Mountains with the Bulldog Recreation Area on the north and the city of Mesa on the west. Goldfield Ghost Town
column3: a tourist location preserved from former prospecting days
column4: lies near the western face of Superstition Mountain just off Highway 88 (Apache Trail). It is located just southwest of the site of the ghost town of Goldfield

column1: == Demographics ==
Apache Junction first appeared on the 1970 U.S. Census as an unincorporated village. It formally incorporated as a city in 1978.
As of the census of 2010
column7: 372 families residing in the city. The population density was 929.3 people per square mile (358.9/km2). There were 22
column8: 771 housing units at an average density of 665.1 per square mile (256.8/km2). The racial makeup of the city was 89.5% White
column14: and 2.4% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino of any race were 14.4% of the population.

column1: == Government ==
Apache Junction was incorporated as a city on November 24
column2: 1978. The city is governed by a collection of elected officials
column4: and nine boards and commissions. The city council has seven members
column5: which includes the mayor and vice-mayor. The mayor serves a two-year term. The current mayor is Jeff Serdy.

column1: == Historic structures ==

This gallery includes images of some of the remaining historical structures located in Apache Junction. Among the exhibits on the grounds of the Superstition Mountain Museum are studio sets and other Western paraphernalia that were saved from the Apacheland fire of 1969. Apacheland was a 1
column2: 800-acre movie set which opened in 1960. Also located in Apache junction  is the ghost town of Goldfield. Goldfield was a mining town established in 1893 next to the Superstition Mountain. When the mine vein faulted
column3: the grade of ore dropped and the town eventually became a ghost town. The town and its historic buildings were revived as a tourist attraction.

column1: Historic Apache Junction
== Transportation ==
Apache Junction is located along U.S. Route 60 in Arizona.
Greyhound Lines serves Apache Junction on its Phoenix-El Paso via Globe route.
